I positively swear that—I asked him if he had brought a fare from Deptford—I asked that to apprehend the prisoner, because he was in conversation with him at Deptford half an hour before I entered the house—I had no doubt he would say he knew nothing about it—the prisoner showed me his badge at Deptford—I was not satisfied whether it was 2696, or 2969: but it was four numbers, and I know the left-hand figure was two—I went to the Badge-office, and found such a badge was not licensed—I then went to the station-house again—they could give me no assistance or information—I then went to the Lord Duncan, at Deptford—they did not know the cabman—directly I saw the prisoner I recognized him, and he said, "That is the man that I 1 brought from Deptford," speaking to me—I had been at work that day from five to one o'clock—I then went from London-bridge to Greenwich, where I transacted some business with an ironmonger—after that, it being fine, I went to Woolwich, and remained there till I lost the last boat to London—I was drinking and enjoying myself at the Waterman—the last steamer started I about a quarter to eight—it was a quarter to one when I started with the prisoner from Deptford—I stopped at Woolwich, after my brother left of ork with his shipmates, till twenty past ten—I then walked through Green-wich to Deptford, and met the prisoner—I did not drink anything after I left Woolwich; I drank nothing at Deptford—I accepted the glass out of the prisoner's hand, and just put it to my lips, but did not drink anything—I had not been in any other house before that—it was the first time I was at the Lord Duncan—I do not know whether I came up the Old Kent-road—I do not know my road about that way—I cannot say whether I car through a toll-bar; I believe there is a toll-bar—I do not know whether it is customary to pay a fresh toll after twelve—I did not pay toll; I swear I did not pay any money after leaving the public-house—I did not pay the prisoner any money before leaving the public-house—I was to pay him 18d., and he was to have a glass of anything he liked to drink, when we got to London—he had a pint of porter, half a quartern of gin, and a pipe of tobacco, before we started, at my expense—it might have been twenty minutes after leaving Deptford that I went to sleep—it might have taken an hour or an hour and a quarter altogether coming from Deptford—I found myself in the Westminster-road about a quarter to two o'clock—I was not sound asleep the whole time, I did not doze the whole time—I tried to amuse myself by looking through the glass, perhaps about a quarter of an hour, and then 1 dozed, and after that I have very little recollection of the objects along the road—I have not the slightest recollection of the toll-bar—I am certain the toll-man did not put his head into the window, and I pay him the toll—we first stopped in the road in a line with Westminster-bridge, very near a night-house there—I know it was in a line with west-minster-bridge, because I went over the bridge afterwards—I do not know the neighbourhood much—I did not know where I was when I first looked out of the cab window when it stopped; I did not know till afterward—I saw

it was not my destination—I was not very sleepy—I thought the prisoner had got off for his own convenience, and I dozed off again—I leaned back—I did not see the waterman there when I was pulled out—I did not stop to see any person—I might have seen him, but did not recognise him—I followed the cab—I am certain the cab did not go on again after I looked out of the win
dow, previous to my being thrown out of the cab—I was not asleep, though dozing—I will undertake positively to swear the cab did not go on after I looked out of the window till I was pulled out—I have no recollection of the caiman stopping and taking up another fare—I do not recollect a woman being in the cab—I heard a woman's voice outside the cab door when it stopped—no person got into the cab after I left Deptford till I was pulled out—a woman and a man did not get in—I am quite sure I was not at all sick during the evening—I had drunk porter and a glass of gin and water, no brandy, nor rum, or wine, or ale, only porter and gin—the jolting of the cab did not make me sick—I am quite positive I was not sick in or out of the cab.

COURT. Q. How long were you under the influence of what you suppose was a stupifying medicine? A. Three hours after I was taken to the station I was not in my original senses; I felt, in fact, completely stupified—while it was strong in operation I felt what occurred to me, but I could not move to resist it—I distinctly felt my pockets rifled—the prisoner said, "I have got a b----old bloke here," speaking to the parties he had about the cab door.

ROBERT JONES (policeman). On Tuesday night, 19th Sept., I was on duty in the Westminster-road, and at a little before two o'clock saw the pri
soner pass me, driving a cab—I had an opportunity of seeing him, his face was towards me—after he had got fifteen or twenty yards he commenced flogging his horse, put it into a gallop, and went down York-road—I saw Cotterell running after the cab along the Westminster-road—he gave an alarm, and told me he had been robbed of his watch, a half-sovereign, 1s. 6d., and some copper—the cab was going very fast down the York-road—the prose
cutor was quite sober—he was excited, but not from drink—he went with me to the station—I found the prisoner in custody on the following Thurs
day, and knew him again.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you seen him before? A. Yes, on different ranks—I was standing under a lamp as he passed me—it was in the bend of the road—it is rather broad—it was at two o'clock in the morning—he did not go very fast till after he had passed me ten or fifteen yards—he turned and looked at me, and the gas shone full in his face—after he passed me he began to whip his horse, and if I had caught the number I should have taken it, for furious driving—that was why I took notice of him—it was about fifty yards from where the prosecutor was, and for that fifty yards, till he passed me, he was cantering his horse, going at the ordinary pace—I saw both the prisoner and the prosecutor before he came up to me—the prosecutor did not give any alarm till he came up to the corner of York-road—he was excited, but not drunk—I did not see him roll over—I cannot say whether there were other people there then, I was not there—two females came up from West
minster-bridge way—there might or there might not have been people coming in the same direction as the prosecutor—I did not notice anybody—the pro
secutor said he had been thrown on the pavement—he said he had either fallen down, or he believed he had been tripped up by one of the prisoner's asso
ciates, as he was pursuing the cab.
JAMES FROST (policeman.) I apprehended the prisoner on Saturday, 25th

Sept., in York-street, York-road—I told him I wanted him for robbing a person in his cab—I hesitated a little, as his wife was there, and told him I would tell him what it was for as we went to the station—he requested me to tell him, and I told him it was for robbing a man of his watch, whom he brought from Deptford in his cab—he said he had brought an old bloke from Deptford, and as he was conveying him to the Westminster-road he took up another fare, and as the fare was in the cab he was sick all over the other parties, and they got fighting in the cab together; that he put the other fare down at the Elephant and Castle, and brought him into the Westminster-road, and thought he had brought him far enough for 1s., and there he bundled him out of the cab, and drove off—as we were going to the Police-court, he said, "I can see the old bloke means to stick to me, I can see it in his ways," or words to that effect—the word "bloke" is a common term used among cabmen—I cannot say the meaning of it.
Cross-examined. Q. When you went to him he at once admitted he had brought a fare from Deptford? A. He did—I believe there is a toll-bar between Deptford and the Westminster-road.

ELIZABETH HAY . I am wife of William Hay, who keeps the Lord Duncan public-house, at Deptford. I recollect the prisoner being in that house on a Tuesday, a fortnight before I was examined—the prosecutor was there, and treated him to half a quartern of gin, a pint of porter, and a pipe of tobacco—I did not see the prosecutor take anything—I did not perceive that he was at all intoxicated—he did not give the prisoner any money in front of the bar.

Cross-examined. Q. He paid for what the prisoner had? A. Yes—I believe the prisoner drank it all—part of the gin was left on the counter, the prisoner drank the rest—I did not see the prosecutor put the glass to his lips—I believe I should have seen him if he had—I was close to him—he did not appear to have been drinking at all when he came in—he seemed a little fatigued—he said he had walked from Woolwich—he came in between twelve and one o'clock, and remained about a quarter of an hour—I saw him and the prisoner start together—the prisoner appeared perfectly sober.

GEORGE HEWETT . I am waterman, at Lambeth-place, Lambeth-square. The prisoner drove up there on the morning of 20th Sept.—I saw him open the cab-door, and the prosecutor came out very quickly, and fell on the pave
ment as he got out—in about two minutes the prisoner got on the box again and drove on very steady, and when he got his horse straight he shoved on, but at a very moderate pace—I did not see him five yards—he did not start at a quick pace.

Cross-examined. Q. He kept a moderate pace during that time? A. Yes—I saw the prisoner open the cab-door, and saw the prosecutor fall on tie pavement that moment—he came out very quickly at the door—I cannot say whether he fell out, or whether he was pulled out—I was very busy at the time—I had three horses in front, and happened to cast my eye that way when the door opened—it was a very short time after the cab drew up, hardly two minutes—the man jumped down off his box and opened the door directly, and the man tumbled out on the pavement.

JURY. Q. Did you see anybody about the cab at the time the man fell out? A. No—the stand is in Mount-street, Westminster-road—the cab stopped on the right side of the watering-place as you come down the New Cut—it is in a straight line with Westminster-bridge.

GEORGE COTTERFLL
re-examined. I did not pay my fare—it was not asked for—I was pulled at of the cab with a great deal of violence, and the
prisoner directly got on the box and drove off—I did not see any one else about the cab when I got up—my watch has not been traced.
(John Alien, tobacconist, gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Transported for Ten Years .

2441.
EDWIN HOUGHTON
, forging and uttering a request for the delivery of goods, with intent to defraud
James Grey; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Twelve Months.
Before Mr. Justice Maule.

2442.
SPENCER LINDFIELD,
MARY ANN DRYDEN , and
RICH
ARD ORPIN were indicted for
the wilful murder of
Eliza Wilson, by pro
curing her miscarriage with the use of a catheter; they were also charged, on the Coroner's inquisition with a like offence.
MESSRS. RYLAND and LAURIE conducted the Prosecution.

SAMUEL ELYARD, ESQ . I am one of Her Majesty's Justices of the Peace for the county of Surrey. On Wednesday, 20th Sept., the deceased, Eliza Wilson, made a statement in my presence and hearing, and signed it—I took it down, but in consequence of her weak, dying state, I had to bend over her in bed, and then I got the police-inspector to write part, in my presence—I had seen her on the previous Sunday—I was requested by the inspector to go there on that day to take the declaration of a dying female—she was then very ill, but she expected to recover, and I therefore went away—on the Wednesday the inspector came again to me, and I went again—I saw her father, and sent for a Clergyman—I asked her how she found herself—she said, "Very ill"—I said, "Do you now think you will recover?"—she said, "No"—I said, "Do you think you will die?"—she said, "Yes"—I then proceeded to take the statement.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. She was lying in her bed at the time, I suppose? A. Yes—the Clergyman, the inspector, the nurse, and myself were in the room—I only addressed to her those observations I have stated—I asked her age—she appeared clearly to understand what she stated to me, though she was extremely weak; and after each sentence the nurse put some moisture to her lips—no one had to repeat what she said—she related the whole herself.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. Did you send for the Clergyman? A. Yes—before I went into the room I had not sent him to her to confer with, as to whether she would recover or not—she wrote her name with very great difficulty, indeed—I believe she died at half-past three o'clock on the Friday morning—it might have been eleven or twelve on the Wednesday that she made the statement.

ROBERT EMERSON (police-inspector). I went with Mr. Elyard to Mr. Wilson's house at Norwood, on 20th Sept., and saw the deceased Eliza Wil
son—I heard her make a statement—I wrote part of it down—this is it—she signed it—(read—" The declaration of Eliza Wilson, taken before me, Samuel Elyard, Esq., at Norwood, 20th Sept., 1848. The said Eliza Wilson having been examined by me as to whether she at present considers herself in a dying state, and she having assured me that she does, is in the thirty-second year of her age, and saith, and suspecting herself to be in the family-way, she made known her suspicion to Richard Orpin, with whom I had had criminal connection, and who would have been the father of the child—I never had connection with any other man—and on my informing him as above, he said, 'Stop till Monday, and we will go together to East-lane, Walworth, to a

woman, but she need not trouble herself for three or four months;' and he went with me on Monday, 4th Sept., to East-lane, but could not find the woman, and on the following day, Tuesday, I went by myself and did not find her, but saw a Mrs. Dryden, who resides in York-street, Walworth, to whom I acquainted that I was in the family-way, and informed her that I wished to get rid of it, and she said it should be all right, if I would pay her 4s., and which I gave her; she gave me a box of pills and a bottle of stuff, which did not have the expected effect. Mrs. Dryden then went with me on the Wednesday to Mrs. Lindfield, to Prior-place, East-street, Walworth, a herb shop. Mrs. Dryden said, 'I have got a friend of mine come to see you.' Mrs. Lindfield, without asking any questions, said, 'I will take her up-stairs directly,' and shortly after did so, and told me to lay on the bed on my left side; she then performed an operation by some instrument, which had some holes at the end. I went again on the 9th, she used the instru
ment again, saying, 'It does not come so freely from you.' I slept at Mrs. Dryden's that night. I paid her, Mrs. Lindfield, 2l. 10s., the first day I went, and gave Mrs. Dryden a few shillings for her trouble in taking me to Mrs. Lindfield. I went to Mrs. Lindfield again on the following Monday, the 11th, when she again used the instrument, when I came home and became ill. I told Mrs. Lindfield my father thought I was ill, and she said, 'Nonsense, you are all right.' Richard Orpin promised to pay the 2l. 10s., but has not done so. The young man, called Mrs. Lindfield's son, was pre
sent on each occasion I went, and was perfectly aware of the business which I was on")—the prisoners were in custody before I saw Wilson—Lindfield's house and premises were searched in my presence—I was present when the catheter, a box containing other instruments, a quantity of herbs and pills, and drugs of almost all sorts, were found—Merritt, the policeman who was present, has them.

JAMES BENSON WILSON . I am the father of the deceased; her name was Eliza—she lived with me at Norwood—she was single, and nearly thirty-two years old—she was ill, and died early in the morning of 22d Sept.—I saw her after death—I had seen her alive on the Thursday night—she first became ill on 12th Sept.—previous to that she had tolerably good health—about a week before she was taken ill she went out, and was out one night and part of two days—I do not know where she went—when she became ill, Mr. Chapman, a surgeon, was sent for, and he attended her till her death.

JAMES WILSON . I am brother of deceased and son of the last witness, and live with him at Norwood. On Thursday, 14th Sept., I took a note from my sister, which she wrote to Mrs. Lindfield, Prior-place, East-street, Wal
worth—the name of Lindfield was on the door—I got there about eleven o'clock at night—I rung twice, and I believe her son came to the door—I inquired for Mrs. Lindfield, and put the note under the door—he went up-stairs, came down again, and I was then admitted, and taken up-stairs into the front room, where Mrs. Lindfield was in bed—she had the note that 1 had taken in her hand—she said, "You come from Norwood?"—I said, "Yes"—she said, "She complains of pain?"—I said yes, she did; she was very bad—I meant my sister—I said she was very bad, and I expected the doctor when I got back—she gave me two ounces of Epsom salts, which I was to give to my sister, and she was to take them in some warm water, and she was to have plenty of warm drink, and likewise to sit on hot water—I asked her what was the matter with my sister—she made no answer, only said she complained of pain—I asked her again—she said that she had the liver complaint, but she was a strong constitution, and she would soon

get over it—I asked how many times my sister had been there—she said twice, once in the week before, and on the Monday—" Epsom Salts" was written on the paper she gave me—she did not say when or how often my sister was to take them, I was to give them to her when I got back—as I was coming away she said I had no occasion to say that she had asked me any questions—I took the salts to my sister, and she took part of them.

WILLIAM WOODWARD (policeman, B 157). On Sunday, 17th Sept., about eight o'clock in the evening, I went to Lindfield's house, 24, Prior-place, East-street—I was in plain clothes—I saw a young man there, named Wil
liam Lindfield—I asked to see Mrs. Lindfield in private, and he took me into a parlour adjoining the shop—I said I came from a young woman, Eliza Wilson, living at Norwood—she asked how she was—I said she was very bad, she was in a feverish state—she asked whether she had taken the medi
cine she had sent by her brother, and put her feet in warm water—I said I did Dot exactly know—I asked her who brought the young woman to her house, and she said a person living in York-street, who sold oysters—I asked her if her name was Dryden—she said she did not know, she had not seen her above twice—she said the person that brought her had given her some pills and a bottle of savin water, which had caused a stoppage in the bowels and the water—I told her I would call again in the morning, and let her know how the young woman was—I then went away—I called again the next morning, about ten, I was shown into the parlour—she asked me how the young woman was—I said, "She is very bad; you are not aware who I am?"—she said, "No"—I said, "I am a police-constable; consider your
self in charge for using a certain instrument on Eliza Wilson, and procuring abortion, and thereby endangering her life"—she then said, "The only instrument I used on her was to draw off the water, and 1 can't recollect whether it was three or four times," she produced this instrument (produced)—I then asked her if she had received any money from the young woman—she said she had had 50s.; 8s. 6d. she had given the woman that brought her, 2s. she charged for medicine, and she had returned Eliza Wilson two sovereigns—this letter was produced by her to the Magistrate, and it has been in my possession ever since (produced).

JAMES WILSON
re-examined. This is the letter I carried from my sister to Mrs. Lindfield—(read—"Norwood, Sept. 14th, 1848.—Mrs. Lindfield, I have sent my brother to inform you I am so bad, I cannot since Monday night move any of my limbs. I have been unwell a little, but nothing else whatever. Pray do not let them into the secret yet; they are very angry because I will not have a doctor. I feel so bad, I think I shall not live, pray send me word what 1 had better do. I am so very much swelled no
thing goes through me. I have taken two doses of castor oil, have the goodness to send me word what had better be done. I have got such a dreadful pain in my left side: my dear Mrs. Lindfield, do send me some ease. E. Wilson.")

THOMAS CANNON (policeman, P 59). I took Dryden into custody on Monday, 18th Sept., in York-street, Lock's-fields, Walworth, about half a mile from East-lane. I told her I was a constable, that Lindfield was in custody, and she was also charged with her with endangering the life of Eliza Wilson, by trying means to procure abortion—she said, "It is through nothing that I have given her, I only gave her some five-leaved grass, ground ivy, and pil. cochice pills; I saw her twice on Monday, and last Monday week"—I asked her if she had received any money from Mrs. Lindfield—she said she had received none, and knew nothing of Mrs. Lindfield, but merely took the female there to

show her the house—she afterwards said she had received 8s. from Mrs. Lindheld, and 3s. from Eliza Wilson for medicine—I then took her into cus
tody—on the following day I apprehended Orpin at Rose Cottage, Chapel road, Norwood—I told him I was a constable, and he was charged with two females then in custody with endangering the life of Eliza Wilson, by per
suading her to take steps to procure abortion—he said, "I know nothing about is"—his wife came into the room, and said, "I do not know whether he is Guilty or not, but I have challenged him with it"—he said, "You had no business to have had her in the house"—the wife said she should not have taken any stuff, and then there would have been nothing the matter with her—Orpin then said, "What stuff she has taken has nothing to do with me"—he asked me who charged him—I said, "I should for the present"—he said, "Whatever she has done is of her own accord; if she takes stuff to poison herself, it is not my fault"—I went to Lindfield's house on the even
ing of 19th, searched it, and found this box of instruments (produced), also a bill of 6l. 10s. 8d. paid by Lindfield to Dryden, which I found in a desk at the end of the counter—she was then in custody—it is a herb shop—her son William lived in the house—I also found a list of herbs.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Was Lindfield's son in custody? A. No—he said he had some bills in the desk—I do not know whether he claimed this one—I do not know whether he claimed the whole of the con
tents of the desk.

WILLIAM MERRITT (policeman). I assisted in searching Lindfield's house—I found a quantity of herbs of which I produce samples—there is some savin—I also searched Dryden's house, and found herbs there, and a small portion of savin—I only know savin by its being pointed out to me as such—I found herbs of different kinds at both places—at Dryden's I found these two bills, and two cards. (These were headed, "Mrs. Lindfield, Midwife, Dentist, and Practical Herbalist, &c," and contained a long list of herbs, ointments, &c., for the cure of various disorders; and the words' retire
ment for ailing females. '")

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Was this likewise found at Lindfield's? A. Yes—(read—"This is to certify that Mrs. Spencer Lind-field has diligently attended a course of my lectures on midwifery, and the diseases of women and children; and practised the same under my inspec
tion.—24th May, 1821.—Henry Gore Clough, M. D., Accoucheur and Phy
sician (to several institutions), Professor and Lecturer on the Science of Midwifery, Berners-street")—these herbs, and a variety of other articles were shown to Dr. Flower, and I believe he examined the whole of them by the direction of the Magistrate—I believe he gave evidence—the desk found at Lindfield's was claimed by her son.

JOSEPH ARMSTRONG (policeman). I have been stationed at Norwood for the last four years—I have known the deceased, Eliza Wilson, and Orpin about four years—they both lived at Norwood—I have seen then together several times; at all hours, between dark, and until half-past one o'clock in the morning, down Thurlow-place, and other parts of the village—I have seen Orpin kiss her.

JOHN CHAPMAN . I am a surgeon at Thurlow-place, Norwood. On 14th Sept., I was called to attend the deceased—I had not known her before—I did not see her till the morning of the 15th—I found her eriously ill. suf
fering from great constitutional disturbance, and apparently in a very danger
ous state—she appeared to be in pain at the lower part of the abdomen—she constantly complained of sickness, but did not vomit while I was there—I

attended her till her death—I consulted with a physician about her case on 16th Sept., and treated her accordingly—in consequence of the complaints she made, I thought it necessary to examine her person—I did that the very first time I saw her—I found indications of a miscarriage taking place—about thirty-six hours after death I made an examination of the body, as
sisted by Mr. Ray—she had certainly been pregnant, and was in my judg
ment seven weeks advanced—(The particulars of the post-mortem examina
tion—and of the cross-examination of this witness, were not of a nature fit for publication; he attributed death to inflammation of the uterus, arising from abortion, but stated that the injury which appeared to have produced that in
flammation was not occasioned by the use of the catheter.)

EDWARD RAY . I am a surgeon, of Dulwich. I assisted Mr. Chapman in the post-mortem examination—I attribute death to the combined effects of inflammation of the bladder, the uterus, and the peritoneum—she had certainly advanced into the second month of pregnancy—abortion had taken place, and I should suppose from unnatural causes.

Cross-examined. Q. It constantly arises from natural causes, does it not? A. It is not common, unless violence is employed—all the appearances I found might have arisen from natural causes if there was severe inflammation—I have not known severe inflammation supervene on abortion—I have read of such cases, even when produced by what I should call natural causes.

ROBERT EMERSON
re-examined. I was present at the examinations of the prisoners before the Magistrate—they were asked if they chose to say any
thing, after the evidence had been taken on both examinations—a statement was made by Mrs. Lindfield on the first examination, and it was read over to her again on the second—she said that was what she wished to state, and I saw the Magistrate sign it—I did not see her sign it—Dryden made a state
ment at the first examination, which was read over to her, and I believe the Magistrate signed it—I know his signature—Orpin made a statement at the last examination—it was read over to him, and I believe the Magistrate signed it—these three signatures are Mr. Norton's—(read—"Spencer Lindfield says: On 4th Sept. this patient (the deceased) was brought to me the first time; she bad been under this woman (Dryden) for a fortnight; she did not under
stand midwifery, and she was brought to me; she said she had been giving her an infusion of savin; that her bowels were so bad she did not know how to bear herself; she (the deceased) said she wished me to examine her; that it was only three weeks since the. intimacy had taken place, and that there had been but one stoppage; I told her that from that period to three months it was my opinion that no midwife could say whether a woman was pregnant or not. I wish that some medical man should examine my hand, to see whether it is in a state to reach the uterus of a person in a rigid state, like this young woman's. I did what I could, but I told her I could prove nothing. I told her to keep her mind easy, and gave her some laxitive medicine. When I tr ied to examine her next time, I had not got my finger more than an inch when I found menstruation coming on again, and I told her to go to bed, and keep her feet warm. I drew her water off for her, as she complained of pain. I gave her an ounce of salts to take home, and I gave her at the same time four pills. I told her to take half an ounce of salts that night, and next day to take two pills, but no salts. I said, 'Take them alternately, till your bowels are relieved.' She complained of costive-ness very much. I did not see her again till that day week, and then she showed me appearances to satisfy me ail was right. She said she was going to see her aunt; she complained that her bowels were still in a constipated

state. I attributed it to the properties of the savin. I heard no more of her till Thursday evening again, when I received this note; then she complained only of the constipation of the bowels, and I sent her two ounces of salts by a young man who brought this note. Dryden did not say she had given her savin; it was the young woman said that, when I took her up stairs privately to examine her. It was the third time the deceased came to me I drew off her water." Dryden says, "She (deceased) had no savin water from me. I gave her rive-leaf grass, ground-ivy, agrimony, and pil. cochioe, which are fine things for the stomach. She asked me if I knew a midwife, and I referred her to Mrs. Lindfield." Orpin says, "I have been out with the young woman several times, but as to giving her poison it is wrong; whatever she took she got it, and took it of her own accord; I neither supplied her with money nor bought it myself; she said something must be done; she came to me, and asked me to give her 30s. to get her some stuff, but 1 told her I would not have anything to do with it, and 1 have not seen her since.")
(Several females deposed to Lindfield's good character, and to her skill as a midwife.")
NOT GUILTY .

(There was another indictment against the prisoners,
charging them with the like murder, by the administration of savin; and also an indictment against Dryden and Orpin
for administering savin, with intent to procure miscarriage; upon which MR. RYLAND offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

2443.
GEORGE PENNY
, for feloniously knowing and abusing
Ann Warner, a girl aged 13 years.

GUILTY of an Assault. —
Confined One Year .
Before Mr. Recorder.

2444.
ADOLPHUS SOLITA
, feloniously killing and slaying
Robert Woodrow.
MR. PLATT conducted the Prosecution.

FRANCES SMITH . I live at 1, Elliott's-place, Lambeth, with my sister, who is the mother of the deceased boy, Robert Woodrow—he would have been thirteen years old next Jan.—he came home on Saturday evening, 9th Sept., from Mr. Randall's, his master, a boot and shoemaker, at Camberwell—he sat down on a chair, and complained of his head aching—I asked what made his head ache, and he said a boy had struck him at the back of his head, and he said to me, "Aunt, feel what a lump I have got?"—I felt a lump, about the size of a nut, behind his ear—I did not think it of any great importance; I thought it was only a cold—he told me his nose had bled at his master's—he went to bed—he awoke me in the night, and his nose was bleeding violently; it poured out all over the bed, I suppose it was more than ten minutes before I could stop it, he went to bed again, it bled again about ten o'clock on the Sunday, and again twice that day, equally violent—he complained of pain in his head—he went to his employment on the Monday, and every day up to the Thursday, but he complained, and was getting worse every day—on the Thursday he came home earlier than usual, and said his head was so bad that he could not do anything at his masters—he went again in the morning, but came home directly, and went to bed—at went again on the Saturday, but he was still very bad, and his master let him come home very early in the evening—he was then very ill indeed, still com
plaining of his head—he never went to work after that—his master asked him to come on the Monday, and he went, but could not stop—on the Thursday following we called in Mr. Thomas, and he attended him till he died, which

was on Friday, 6th Oct.—I was speaking to him a short time before he died—he told me he was sure he should die that night, and he did die that night—I said to him, "My dear, you are on your death-bed now; are you sure that what you said to those gentlemen, (meaning Mr. Norton, the Magistrate, and his clerk,) was the truth?"—he said, "Yes, aunt; was I to die this moment, what I said was the truth"—several times in the course of his illness he said if he died that boy would be the cause of his death who he had pointed out to me as we were going to Camberwell—the prisoner had passed us, and he said, "That is the boy that hit me on the head."—he did not say that loud enough for the prisoner to hear—he took an oath, when the Magistrate was there, that he never knew a boy of the name of Cole, or Coles—he repeatedly told me during his illness that he never knew nothing of a boy named Cole—he never, at the time he was dying, said anything about a boy named Cole—about half an hour before he died, I asked him whether he had been fighting, and he said, "No, I never have; I never fought with any boy"—I mentioned the name of Cole to him, and he said he did not know a boy of that name.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. When was it he pointed out the prisoner? A. On the second Wednesday after he was taken ill—he said, "Aunt, that was the boy that struck me on the head"—I did not know Solita till he pointed him out to me—I did not then know who he was—I did not follow him to find out—the deceased said he lived close by his master's—I did not go to his father, or to the boy, and speak to him—when Mr. Thomas found out what was the matter with him, I went to the police-station—the deceased's mother was ill in bed at the time—Solita's father is a tailor, or draper—I suppose he lived with his father—he had nothing to do with our boy—I swear that he had not been an ailing boy long before the 9th Sept.—he did not wear a handkerchief round his head till after he received the blow; never before that—I have brought him up—I hear that a man has come to swear that he used to wear a handkerchief, and I have a witness to prove he did not—he never cried and complained of his head before—he has said he has had the ear-ache, but never of any consequence—he never cried about it—he has complained but very seldom, when he has had a cold, as many children will—I have noticed a discharge of thick matter from his ear sometimes, but very trifling—I have not done anything for it, but left it to cure itself.
MR. PLATT. Q. Are you a mother? A. No, but I have always been with children—it is not uncommon for children, when they have a cold, to have a discharge at the ear—a healthy child will often have it.

JOHN PETER PERRY . I am clerk, at Lambeth Police-court. The prisoner was taken to the house of the deceased boy's mother, as the boy was too ill to be brought to the office, and this deposition was taken there before Mr. Norton, the Magistrate, who attended—I was present, and the prisoner also—he heard what the deceased stated—it was taken down by me, in presence of the Magistrate, and signed by him—this is his signature—it was read over to the deceased, but he was too ill to sign it—he appeared to me to possess his faculties, and to understand what passed, until the latter part of the de
position; he then became exhausted, and murmured, and seemed to be very anxious that there should be an end of it—at the latter part he mistook Mr. Norton for the surgeon, and asked his permission to have something to drink—when the deposition was concluded he said, "That will do, that will do," rather impatiently; but he was sensible up to that time—the deposition was given, in answer to questions put by Mr. Norton—I correctly took down the

substance of what he said—sometimes the question had to be repeated once or twice—he was exhausted, and had to be raised—it was taken on the 4th Oct.—(deposition read—"Robert Woodrow, on his oath, says: 'I am getting on for thirteen. I swear that that boy hit me; it was on Saturday He hit me with his fist in the back of my head, near the ear. I do not know why he hit me. He hit me with his fist, nothing else; I did not see any
thing else. I met him opposite Mr. Mayhew's. He did not say anything before he hit me; he hit me hard. He ran after me. I do not know the cause of his hitting me; I had had no quarrel with him. He said nothing to me before he struck me. I knew him before this. I never quarreiled with him. I know his name; it is Adolphus. I have known him a good while, Cross-examined. I had not been fighting the day before with a boy named Cole, in Walworth; I do not know a boy of that name. I had not beer, fighting with anybody. Re-examined. I told my mother of it when I came home.'")—There was a statement made by the prisoner at the police-court—I took it down in the Magistrate's presence, and he signed it—(reads—"I have nothing to say; but one morning he asked me if I would fetch some white mice for him, and I refused. I was coming across the green the last time I saw him before I went into his room. He was at some distance, and did not see me. I did not strike him; I had nothing to strike him for.")

SAMUEL JOHN THOMAS . I am a surgeon, in the London-road. I was seat for, and first visited the deceased on 21st Sept.—he complained of great pain in his head and behind his right ear—I examined it, but perceived nothing, and considered it was a disorder within the head that caused him to complain of pain there—there was no discharge—I went again on the Sunday follow
ing, and he then complained of having received a blow—the aunt told me first, and the boy himself afterwards—in consequence of that I examined the parts behind the ear, and on shaving the hair, found a small tumour on the projecting part of the bone—feeling there was matter or some fluid there, I made an incision, and there flowed a small quantity of pus, or matter, very foetid—I saw him daily after that—on the Tuesday following, not considering the incision free enough, I made a larger one, and a small quantity more matter escaped, still very foetid—he gradually got worse—I attended him till he died, which was about twelve, or a little after twelve, on the night of 6th Oct., so 1 was informed—I afterwards made a post mortem examination—on dividing the scalp, I found that portion situated over where the abscess was, in a gangrenous condition, and the pericranium was separated from the skull—it did not adhere as it ought to do—that was precisely over the tumour—the skull beneath the bone, beneath the section of the tumour, was in a state of necrosis or mortification—on examining the inner portion of the skull more particularly, which contains the passage to the internal ear, it was in a very much more advanced state of mortification—the dura mater had a large patch of ulceration upon it immediately beneath the affected portion of the bone and scalp, and on removing the dura mater I found a portion of the bone in a slightly inflamed state—there was a small quantity of reddish white matter on the dura mater, not like that which had escaped from the tumour—that was evidence of decomposition, arising from extended inflammation or fever—in my opinion death was caused by irritative fever, the result of this inflamma
tion and destruction of the parts—there was a small quantity of fluid in the ventricles of the brain, rather more than natural—hearing that he had received a blow, I should ho inclined to suspect that that was the cause of the disease under which he laboured, the fever, the inflammation, and the destruction of

the parts—it might have occurred from spontaneous necrosis, it does so some
times, without any external injury, if it is in the system—I cannot say that this was caused by external violence, I think it probable, but I could not say so positively—a very slight blow will sometimes produce necrosis in an unhealthy subject—necrosis does not affect the head so frequently as it does other parts of the body, as the legs or arms—the effect of a blow behind the ear would be very sensibly felt, because a variety of important nerves and veins pass in that direction—the discharge from the ear could not of itself cause death, but it might have been the result of a disease which would—he died of mortification—I did not take blood from him, he was not in a con
dition to bear it, the disease had gone so far—there was no symptom of any discharge in the other ear—I discovered nothing in his system to show a predisposition to any complaint in the ear, but I was not acquainted with his previous history—if he had disease, a blow would probably render it worse and accelerate death.

Cross-examined. Q. Was the boy a strumous or scorbutic subject? A. Not that I am aware of—I cannot tell either one way or the other—if there is a purulent discharge from the ear, that must arise from some disease either within the ear, or deeper—irritative fever is sometimes accompanied by deli
rium—I only perceived that he was light—headed on one occasion, five or six days before his death, but I heard that he had been delirious in the night—I gave a very small quantity of soothing medicine, not so much to subdue the irritation as from the great disturbance of the bowels—he was suffering from profuse diarrhoea—that would not, if it did not act as intended, produce wan
dering, not in the small doses I gave it, and combined with other medi
cines—it will do so sometimes, but the medicine did act as I intended—it was only administered on one or two occasions—I cannot say that the mark behind the ear was produced by a blow—the gangrene covered a space of four inches in length and two in breadth—all the symptoms were those of inflammation.
MR. PLATT. Q. Might not discharge from the ear take place from a common cold? A. Yes, it is frequently the case with children.

JOHN SWAN FLOWERS . I am a surgeon at Camberwell—I assisted Mr. Thomas in the post mortem examination—I have heard his evidence, and concur with him so far as this, that I consider the boy died from irritative or hectic fever, caused by an abscess which had formed on the brain—apart from what we have heard as to a blow, it might have arisen from natural causes, from an abscess generated in the system, without external violence, particu
larly in a strumous habit of body, or one of delicate formation—if there was a predisposition, a blow would accelerate it—in my opinion disease was ex
isting prior, probably, to the receipt of any blow, and that was indicated by the discharge from the ear—if he had received a blow, and this had been a consequence, I should have anticipated more disturbance of the head, bis intellect would not have been so good as it was, and there would have been vomiting—he ought to have been kept perfectly quiet—if the abscess was caused by a blow, it must have been a very violent one, and in a very bad state of constitution—I should not think a blow from the hand of a boy like the prisoner would produce it.

FRANCES SMITH
re-examined. The deceased first mentioned having re
ceived the blow the same night, when he came home, and said a boy had struck him—he did not then say what boy, I did not ask him—it was on the Wednesday week afterwards that he pointed out the prisoner—he was very

poorly from the Saturday, till he died—he sunk daily, and was always com
plaining of his head, and when he was washed he would say, "Don't hurt me where the boy struck me"—still we did not think it was anything further than a cold—I felt the lump there, but I did not believe it was owing to a blow till he pointed out the prisoner and said, "That is the boy that hit my poor head."

STEPHEN HARRIS (policeman, P 49). The prisoner was given into my charge on 26th Sept.—I told him he was charged with striking a lad named Robert Wood row—he said, "I did not strike him; I never have struck him"—he said that twice, once to me and once to his father.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe his father asked him two or three times, and pressed him very much to tell the truth? A. He did, and he persisted in saying that he did not strike him—he said it very earnestly, and seemed quite surprised when I told him the charge.

SAMUEL JOHN THOMAS
re-examined. If this had been produced by a blow, I should have expected the symptoms to have followed rather more quickly—he did alternately get a little better and worse, and there seemed at one time some little probability that he might recover, until diarrhoea set in—he then became exceedingly thirsty, and cried much for ginger-beer, and his friends supplied him rather profusely with it, to pacify him, and that tended to keep up and increase that intestinal irritation, and thereby his condition of course became worse—he sank more rapidly.
NOT GUILTY .

2445.
ELIZA DAVIS, alias Jane King
, uttering counterfeit coin, after a previous conviction.
MESSRS. ROBINSON and METCALFE conducted the Prosecution.

CALEB EDWARD POWELL . I am assistant-solicitor to the Mint. I pro
duce a copy of the record of Eliza Davis's conviction at this Court, in March, 1847—I have examined it with the original, it is a true copy (read).
JOHN LEE (policeman, N 179). I was present when the prisoner was tried in March, 1847—she is the person.

JOHANNA PRIDLEY . I am a widow, and am a cheesemonger at Dock-bead. On Saturday, 16th Sept., between eight and nine in the evening, the prisoner came to my house for a quarter of a pound of butter, and gave me a five-shilling piece—I took twopence-halfpenny, and gave her the change—I did not look at the crown, but threw it into the till—there was another crown there—I took no notice what sort of a crown it was—I afterwards took out two crowns; one was a new Victoria one, and my daughter said, "I took that"—the other was an old one—there were none but those two in the till—I can swear the prisoner is the person—I took particular notice of her.

MARY ANN PRIDLEY . I am daughter of the last witness. On 16th Sept. I received a crown-piece in payment of a bill—it was a Victoria crown—I generally observe the reign of money when I take it—it looked new and bright—I put it into the till—not many minutes after, I saw the prisoner in the shop—I believe my mother was serving her—West the policeman came in soon after she left—this crown is of the same reign as the one I received——I made no mark on it—my attention was called to it by West, not more than five minutes after I put it into the till.

JOHN WEST (policeman, M 249). On Saturday night, 16th Sept., I saw the prisoner with a man—as they passed Mrs. Pridley's shop I saw them notice it—they passed it about a hundred yards, stopped, talked, and both turned back again; the female on the same side as the shop, and the man on

the opposite side—I saw the prisoner enter Mrs. Pridley's shop, and served with some butter, and take some change—as soon as she left the shop I went in, spoke to Mrs. Pridley, and she gave me these two crown-pieces—I lost sight of the prisoner when I got out of the shop again—I am certain she is the person—I suspected, and watched her.

ELIZABETH PEATMAN . My husband keeps a grocer's-shop at Dock—head. On 16th Sept., about half-past eight, the prisoner came and bought some herrings and onions, which came to twopence—she gave me this crown-piece (produced), and I gave her the change—I kept the crown in my hand, showed it to my husband, marked it, and gave it to Whitlamb—our shop is not more than two minutes' walk from Mrs. Pridley's.

ISABEL LOUISA COCKLEY . I am the daughter of Mr. Cockley, a cheesemon
ger, at North-buildings, Bermondsey. On 16th Sept., about a quarter to nine o'clock, the prisoner came, asked for some butter, and tendered me a five-shiiling-piece—I passed it to my mother—she detained it, marked it in my presence, sent for a policeman, and gave the prisoner in custody with the crown.

MARY ANN COCKLEY . On 16th Sept. I received this crown-piece (pro
dued) from my daughter, and gave it to the policeman—the prisoner was in the shop at the time—I marked it at the station, and gave it to the policeman.

CALEB EDWARD POWELL
re-examined. The three crowns are counterfeit, and cast in the same mould—a great deal of the sharpness in the lettering is lost, and at the edges you can see where they have been cut off from the get here is a mark which was on the good piece that made the mould, and it has been transferred to all these three—if they were good that would not occur—many people would take them for good, they do pass into circulation to a very great extent—they are silvered by-means of a voltaic battery.
Prisoner. I beg for mercy; I have a child wholly dependent on me for support; want and bad company are the cause of what I have done.

2446.
WILLIAM HUGHES
, feloniously cutting and wounding
Eliza Moynehan on the head, with intent to do her some grievous bodily harm.

p.hi: being called on her recognizance did not appear.

div1.p:
ELEANOR JENKINS . I live at No. 22, Union-square, Tooley-street. Eliza Moynyon lodged with me fifteen months; the prisoner has been in the habit of visiting her for a year—on Tuesday morning, 10th Oct., they both went out about six o'clock, and returned about one, both intoxicated—they went into the room—I heard some quarrelling, I jumped out of bed, and went to try and quiet them—I parted them as well as I could—the woman was un
dressed and the prisoner was near her—I saw him give her a blow on her head with his fist—she fell on the bed and he kicked her in the head while she was lying there—she was bleeding from the head—I sent for a policeman—two came, and the prisoner was taken in custody, and Moynehan went to the hospital—I cannot be positive how many times he kicked her—he kept kick
ing her on the head.
Prisoner. I have no recollection of it; I was very much intoxicated. Witness. They lived together peaceably before this—they did have a few-words, but there was no act of violence like this before.

WILLIAM HINCHCLIFF (policeman, M 85). Between one and two o'clock, on the morning of 10th Oct., I went to Jenkins's house—in consequence of what she told me I went into the back-room, and saw the prisoner holding

himself by the left hand, by the washhand-stand, and kicking Moynehan with the heel of his boot, as she was lying on the bed undressed, with her head towards the bottom—I saw him kick her violently with the heel of his boot twice—she was covered with blood—I seized him, and pulled him away into the next room—I told another constable to take charge of him, for I did not know whether he had killed the woman or not—I then went back, lifted her up, and in about a quarter of an hour she came to herself—I counted seven wounds on her head—I took her to the hospital, and after a week she was let out, to go before the Magistrate, but she never came, and the Magistrate granted a warrant to apprehend her—I found her in Tooley-street, not in the same house—I took her on the warrant, and she gave evidence before the Magistrate, and was bound over to prosecute—I have not seen her since.

GEORGE HOOPER (policeman M 179). I went to Jenkins's—the prisoner ran out of the door—I pursued him bout 100 yards, and took him into cus
tody—he ran very fast indeed—he did not appear drunk—he asked me what I took him for.

ALGERNON SUDLOW . I am house-surgeon at Guy's Hospital. Eliza Moynehan was brought there—I examined her head, and found seven incised wounds, which seemed to have been bleeding profusely—blood was still oozing from some of them, and there was a great deal of contusion round some of them—she appeared very much excited—I have seen the pri
soner's boots—they are mounted with iron, and might make the wounds—a person leaning on a washhand-stand and kicking behind him, would be capable of kicking with considerable force—the woman was in the hospital seven or eight days, and attended twice afterwards as an out-patient—I did not examine the depth of all the wounds; I do not think the bone was reached—she went on very well indeed—she was in a very healthy state of body—erysipelas might have followed—when she first came she was quite insensible, and had the appearance of being drunk—that might be caused by the blows she had received—she complained of headache.
Prisoner's Defence. We have been together very comfortable since, and always were before, except for drink.

GUILTY of an Assault. Aged 27.—
Confined Nine Months.

2447.
ANDREW BASKERVILLE and
JAMES ANDERSON
felo
niously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John Holland Ray, and stealing 1 shawl and other articles, value 11s.; his goods; to which

BASKERVILLE pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 25.

ANDERSON pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 18.

2448.
THOMAS PARSONS
, stealing 19lbs. weight of pot-metal, and 1 metal waste, value 8s.; the goods of
William Pontifex and another, his masters.

JOHN SHARP . I am manager to William and Edward Pontifex, copper-smiths and engineers. The prisoner has been in their employ about fourteen years—on the evening of 13th Oct. I saw him leaving the premises, and I kept him in conversation to point him out to the officer—I have seen the metal produced—it is called pot-metal—I have no doubt it is the property of Messrs. Pontifex—I can swear to this article, it is a rough casting—it is never sold or sent out in the state it is now in.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. What is it called? A. Waste—it is part of a washer and waste—it is made to fix in a washer—I cannot say that I had seen this on the premises.

JAMES BURTON (policeman M 272). I watched the prisoner—I saw him come out of the factory—I took him in a passage in Gravel-lane, Southwark, at the back of a marine-store dealer's shop—I told him I suspected he had got some property he had brought from his employers'—he said, "It is a bad job, it is the first lot I brought from my employers"—I found this metal on him, some in his hat, and some in different pockets.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 52.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury. —
Confined Four Months.

2449.
JOHN BEARD
, stealing 1 coal-scuttle, value 7s.; the goods of
James Edward Lawrence; having been before convicted; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 41.—
Confined Six Months.
Before Mr. Common Serjeant.

2450.
WILLIAM HISCOCK
, stealing 2 shillings, 3 sixpences, 2 pence, and 3 halfpence; the moneys of
George Wells, his master.

GEORGE WELLS . I keep the Coopers' Arms, at Putney. The prisoner was in my service—on 26th Sept. I marked some money, and put it in dif
ferent places where I had lost money from before—I put 16s. 6d. into a bag in a drawer, four sixpences in the till, and 1s. worth of halfpence—I locked up the bar and the places—the next morning at eight o'clock. I came, and missed two shillings and a sixpence out of one place, and 3 1/2 d. out of another—the money was all found on the prisoner by the officer—we went up stairs, and found in his box brandy and wine and cheroots, and a great many other things.

CHARLES CANHAM (policeman, V 58). I was secreted in the house—I saw the prisoner come down at half-past seven o'clock in the morning—he went into the bar-parlour—I heard a drawer and a till go—I waited till Mr. Wells came—I told him, and this money was gone—we found the marked money on the prisoner—I had seen it marked—it was the same money—I found this other property in the prisoner's box.
Prisoner's Defence. I opened the door: I saw some money down on the mat, and took it up. (The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined One Year .

2451.
MARY DONOVAN
, stealing 6 sheets, and 1 gown, value 14s.; the goods of
William Poole and another; having been previously convicted.

WILLIAM POOLE . I am a pawnbroker, and have one partner. On 11th Oct. the prisoner came to our house, and I saw her take down a gown, and conceal it beneath her clothes, and a bundle of sheets, and put them under her shawl—she left the shop, saying she would call again in the afternoon—I followed her, and asked her to walk back with me, and I saw her drop these things from under her shawl, and from under her petticoats—I had not sold them to her—she had no right to them.

Prisoner's Defence. I had had a little too much to drink, and he chaffed roe; I could not have-stolen them; I beg for mercy, on account of my poor children; I never was in the hands of a policeman but once before; I have worked nine years for one master.

JOHN DELANY (policeman, M 100). I produce a certificate of the pri
soner's
former conviction—(read—Convicted Jan., 1848: confined twenty-one days)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 32.—
Confined Nine Months.

2452.
JANE HAMPTON
, stealing 28 yards of flannel, value 18s. 6d.; the goods of
George Pym; having been previously convicted; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 37.—
Confined Nine Months.

2453.
JOHN LAWRENCE and
HENRY VAUGH
, stealing 1 bag, value 2d.; the goods of
William Charles Fidler; to which

LAWRENCE pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 14.

VAUGH pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 14.

Confined There Months and
Whipped .

2454.
HANNAH PITTMAN
, stealing 1 half-sovereign; the moneys of
George Pinnock, her master; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Three Months.
Before Mr. Recorder.

2455.
WILLIAM ALGER SPENCER
, stealing 1 coat, value 14s.; the goods of
Matthew Bird; having been before convicted; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Transported for Seven Years .

2456.
JOHN FITZGERALD
, stealing 1 purse, value 6d.; 2 sovereigns, and 2 half-sovereigns: also, 3 sovereigns, 5 half-sovereigns, I crown, 9 half-crowns, and 1 shilling: the property of
William Augustus Green, in his dwelling-house: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 13.—
Confined Fourteen Days and
twice Whipped .
Before Mr. Common Serjeant.

2457.
JOHN EVENDEN
, stealing 8 cigars, value 2s.; the goods of
Isaac Crawcour, having been before convicted; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined One Year .

2458.
WILLIAM PARSONS
, stealing 1 purse, value 6d.; 1 pocket, 6d.; 32 sovereigns, and 15 shillings; the property of
Sarah Adams.

SARAH ADAMS . I am single, and lodge at 103, Blackfriars-road. I have been in service in France—I came to London, and met the prisoner on 3rd Oct.—I asked him to show me a lodging—I had then thirty-two sovereigns—he took me to 61, White Horse-street—he told me I was quite safe, as if I was in my own house—he left me about an hour and a half—he came back, and took my pocket off the chair—I hallooed, and told him to put it down—he put his hand into it, and took the money—I got up and seized him by the wrists—he twisted himself from me, got away, and ran out of the door—I begged him to come back, but he would not—I returned, and called the per
son of whom I took the room—she said she knew him—he was one of her father's clubmates—she took me to a house, but it was the wrong person.

Prisoner. Q. What time did you meet me? A. About twenty minutes to nine o'clock, you asked me to go into a public-house—I do not know what house it was—I was drinking there between eight and nine—I was not asleep when you took the money—there was a light in the room.
COURT. Q. How did you come by the money? A. I had been saving it up five years—I left my master's last July—I was not going to sleep with
the prisoner—I never saw him before—he was sitting half an hour with me, assuring me that I was safe.

MARIA MAYHEW . My father keeps a lodging-house, in White Horse-Street. The prisoner introduced the prosecutrix between eight and nine o'clock, and asked if I had got a bed for the night—I went down and got a light, and took them up to the room—he had been up about half an hour—he then came over to the opposite house to me about ten—he was out about an hour and a half or two hours—he came in again, and was up stairs five minutes, he came down, and asked if I would have something to drink—I said, "No"—he pulled me to go, and take something—I would not—he said it was all right, he was a club-mate of my father's—when I went up with him first I asked him to turn the key of the door in the morning as the land
lord did not lodge in the house—he said he should not go till half-past eight—if the prosecutrix had come to the door I should have seen her, because I was opposite—I did not hear of the robbery till the morning, when she came and said, she had been robbed of 32l. 15s., and asked if I should know the man—I said, "Yes, he told me he was a club-mate of my father's"—I gave my father the description of him in the morning, and he told me it was another man.

JAMES FROST (policeman, L 59). I took the prisoner in bed the next night at Broadwall, four or five hundred yards from Mayhew's—while I was. searching, the prosecutrix came and wished to compromise the case.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Recorder.

2459.
THOMAS JOHNSON
, stealing 1 firkin, value 6d.; 90 lbs. Weight of butter, 3l.; the goods of
Edmund Goodman, having been before con
victed; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Nine Months.

2460.
EDWARD JOHNSON,
WILLIAM JONES , and
ROBERT HANLON
, stealing 1 pocket-book, value 2s. 6d.; the goods of
James Saxby Jarvis. from his person; Johnson having been before convicted; to which

JONES pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Confined Nine Months.

JAMES SAXBY JARVIS . I live at Union-place, Lambeth. On 26th Sept., in the evening, I was in Black friars-road—as I turned the corner of Stam
ford-street, I saw the prisoners larking—a little farther on Johnson came before me—I pushed him on—he kept before me—I shoved him aside once or twice—Hanlon was on my left—Johnson stopped short, got under my legs and tried to lift me up—I felt something touch my pocket and took hold of Jones's hand with my pocket-book in it—Hanlon was holding my pocket up—he ran away—I found him next morning at the station—I secured Jones, two gentlemen stopped Johnson—his head was tied up then, and I know him well.
AMBROSE FURMINGO (policeman, L 162). I was on duty, and saw Jones and Johnson together about an hour before the robbery—I took them from Mr. Jarvis.

WILLIAM POUND . I am a shoemaker of Duke-street, Westminster. I was a witness against Johnson by the name of
Benjamin Lawson, and produce a certificate of his conviction—(read—Convicted September, 1847, and confined three months)—he is the person.

JOHNSON—
GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Confined Nine Months.

HANLON—
GUILTY , and received a good character.—Aged 16.—
Confined Fourteen Days .
Before Mr. Common Serjeant.

2461.
LOUISA STEVENSON
, stealing 16 yards of silk, value 3l. 12s.; the goods of
Joseph Harvey:
also 46 yards of silk, and other goods, 5l. 10s. 6d.; the goods of
John Tarn and another, in their dwelling-house-to which she pleaded

2462.
JOHN MCCARTHY
, feloniously cutting and wounding
George Quinnear upon his head, with intent to do him grievous bodily harm.—2nd COUNT, to resist and prevent the lawful apprehension of a person unknown.
MESSRS. BODKIN and CLERK conducted the Prosecution.

WILLIAM SMITH (policeman, P 32). I was on duty on 7th Oct., about seven o'clock, in the Walworth-road, with George Quinnear—we were in plain clothes—I saw the prisoner with another man, who had his hand in a lady's pocket—the prisoner was walking close behind him, covering him—I said I am a constable—I took the prisoner, Quinnear took hold of the other—the prisoner got away from me—I lost sight of him for a minute or two—I communicated with the lady—while the other man was scuffling with Quin
near, the prisoner returned, went up, and struck Quinnear on the head with what had the appearance of a small stick—he immediately fell—I caught the prisoner striking a second blow; he struck me with this instrument on the forehead—I saw blood come from Quinnear—several persons were behind, beating me about the head—my hat was broken all to pieces—the stick appeared about a foot and a half long—the blow appeared to be more severe than a stick of that length would give, that was not weighted at the end.

GEORGE QUINNEAR (policeman, C 201). I was with Smith, and saw the prisoner and the man with him, with his hand in the lady's pocket—I took that man—I was struggling with him—he was trying to shift out of his coat—the prisoner came up—he took a short stick from his dress, and gave me a deliberate and violent blow on the head, which broke my hat and cut my head—I was felled to the ground—the stick appeared to be very heavy at the end—I still kept hold of the man, and as I was falling the prisoner struck me again on the shoulder, and the other man escaped, and left his coat and hat behind—I bled, and was taken to the doctor's—I had told the man I was a police-officer—I have been unfit for duty till this time.

ENOCH DAWSON HOWITT . I am a surgeon. On 7th Oct. Quinnear was brought to my house—I examined his head, and found a clean incised wound, about three-quarters of an inch long, such as might have been inflicted by a severe blow from a stick—it corresponded with the holes in the hat—it would require a heavy blow to cut through the hat, and produce that wound—if the stick had not been loaded, I should say it would not have done it.
Prisoner. Some one struck me on the side of my head, I turned and struck the officer; I did not know he was an officer; I never had a stick; there were two witnesses who have not been called.

WILLIAM HINTON
examined by the Prisoner. I saw you strike with you: fist, but not with a stick—you had a stick in the first instance.
THOMAS BARBER . I saw Smith take you, and you struck him two or three times with your fist.

GUILTY . ** Aged 27.—
Transported for Ten Years .

2463.
EDWIN JOSEPH LUCAS
, stealing 3lbs. of printing type, leads, and other articles, value 6s.; the goods of
Henry Silverlock, his master.
MR. PARRY conducted the Prosecution.

HENRY SILVERLOCK . I am a printer in Wardrobe-terrace, Doctors'-com
mons. The prisoner was in my employ as overseer or foreman—his wages were 50s. a week—he had access to all parts of my office and stock—I employ sixty or seventy men—I went with the policeman to the prisoner's house in Blackfriars-road, on 26th Sept.—one officer went in the back premises with my foundry-man, and there found some metal lead—I did not go with him—I found this metal block, or moulding, in the front room, on the first-floor—I believe it to be mine—this cast is made use of in the working of the wrapper of the Patent Journal—that is a work that has been printed on my premises—the prisoner would have no business to take any type or mould from my premises to his own—this is stereotyped—I had printed the Journal about a year and a half—I was not present when the prisoner was given into custody—I had not charged him with it before I went to his premises.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. How long had he been in your service? A. About two years—I printed a work called the Nautical Standard—the prisoner was not originally employed in my jobbing business, but on the Nautical Standard—he was put on it about April—that was what he first came to work upon—he had no other employ to attend to then—he was I think on piece work—he earned about 36s. a week—Jones, my over
seer left me, and the prisoner being a steady young man I put him in the place, and increased his wages to 50s.—Jones' wages were 60s. a week—he was only overseer, the prisoner was overseer, and had the printing of the Nautical Standard—Jones also had the superintendence of that—Mr. Bar
low was the proprietor of the journal—the prisoner was not in custody when we searched his house—he was in my employ—I took my founder, Hicks, with me to the prisoner's premises—I did not give the prisoner any notice, or make any charge against him at that time—I ceased to be printer of the Patent Journal the week before—I knew when I went to search his pre
mises on the 26th, that I was no longer to be continued the printer of the Patent Journal—I gave the prisoner notice to quit my employ on the 18th Sept.—I did not at that time know that he was going to be taken into the employ of Messrs. Barlow and Co., to be employed on the Patent Journal—I knew it on the Friday following, before I searched his house—all that I can recognise of these articles amount to 6s. in value—the printing of the Patent Journal did produce a profit, but a very small one—I believe this block to be mine, as far as a man can speak to property on his premises—I mean to swear to it—it had been made for myself—I know a person named Miller—(looking at a sheet)—this is not the impression of my block—nor is this other—(looking at another)—here is part of it here—this one has been cut and pieced about—this centre appears to be it, but the top and bottom have both been cut off—Miller had nothing to do with this casting—he had to do with some former blocks—these were at one time in separate casts—they were sent to me to work, and I cast them for my own convenience—the small blocks I have no doubt went hack to Mr. Barlow, or Mr. Miller as their agent, but this block was never out of my premises—I know that Cap
sey and Cole, two men who were in my service, lodged in the same house with the prisoner—I did not employ them, or either of them to make any search at the house—after I heard that he was going on the Patent Journal they went there, being anxious to find out the guilt—I told all the men in my employ that property was missing, and every man must look out—I deny that I gave them authority, or direction to make any search there—I believe Capsey and Cole, and the prisoner all left my service together—it was not at my instance that Capsey and Cole left, nor by any interference of mine—I

had no reason to believe before I gave the prisoner into custody that he had received this block from Miller's hand—I had never been told so before he was in custody—in coming out of the Court, Miller said, "That has been in my possession"—I learnt with utter astonishment from Miller, when I was at the station, or police-court, that he had given this to the prisoner—he did not say he gave it to the prisoner—he said it had been in his possession—I knew the prisoner was about to be employed on the Patent Journal, and that Miller told me it had been in his hands—I did not ask whether Miller gave it him—from a memorandum found, it appears that Miller gave it him on the previous day—this plate would be of no use to anybody that did not print the Patent Journal—Messrs. Barlow and others were about to employ the prisoner to print it.

MR. PARRY. Q. Look at this other property, which do you identify? A. This is a plate that is partly melted—it is a stereotype plate of "genuine Court-plaister"—these leads have a particular mark on them—here is a little round mark, slightly indented, which arises from a little defect in the mould—almost every one of these has the mark—this one I cannot identify, but ray foundryman does.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. I believe you stated it to be yours from the remain
ing impression of the plug mark? A. Yes, and no other—on this piece of lead which has been partly melted", there is the stamp of Court-plaister—if he had taken any impression of one of my leads for the purpose of enabling him to make more by it, it would not have the same impression that mine has—it is too fine a mould—I did not employ a reporter to take down the evidence before the Magistrate, and afterwards publish it—I had a communi
cation with a gentleman who sits below me—the second day we were at the office he came there—I had seen and known him some years—my communi
cation to him was that I had been robbed, and that it was coming on at the police-court, and he was to come down—he was not to take a report—there was a reporter there—I did not employ him to report the case—there was another reporter at the office, but 1 was not acquainted with matters of this kind—a reporter reporting at a police-court must know these things—I never was in a police court—I knew there was a regular reporter there, and I told this gentleman, and he came—I will not say that I did, or did not tell him to come—I do not believe that I did—I have no recollection that I did—I had continual communication with him in the police-court while the case was going on—that person did not report the case—the case was reported by another reporter—I think it was not reported by him on the second occasion—I do not think he would have made the mistakes that were made—I did not speak to him till the case had been before the Magistrate.

Q. Just understand me; supposing one of these to be used as a model, and put into a mould, would not the impression it made have this effect, that if metal were poured into the mould, it would come out with the same deficien
cies as this—it would make an entire assimilation of it? A. No, because casting in a metal mould would be entirely different from a sand mould—I know the prisoner was casting, because it was found on bis premises—the Queen's Arms on the "Court-plaister" stamp had never been thrown into the refuse box to my knowledge—I do not know that any of these had been worn enough to have been put into the waste metal box—they might have been condemned by the printer, and then they would be, but it so happened that this was not printed lately—these lead types I charge to be of the value of 1s. 6d., the mould casting 2s., the Court-plaister and the King's Arms 2s., and the brass rules at 6d.; making altogether 6s.—I do not know that the

prisoner has been in the habit of taking metals for the purpose of casting—I never heard from any of my servants that he was in the habit of taking these sort of things one at a time for the purpose of moulding and returning them—I had been told so by one, that is a witness named Fall, a few days back—I cannot say when—he took me, and pointed out some of the very things that he had taken from my premises to mould.

MR. PARRY. Q. Before this charge was preferred, had you missed pro
perty? A. I had—I have no idea of the amount, there are many tons of metal, it would be impossible—the whole value I charge is 6s.—the value is depreciated by being fused—this metal might be fused metal-type—I do not identify this as my property—a man has shown me some casting of the prisoner's—this is a portion of a stereotype-plate—part of it has been melted down—that is an act which the prisoner would have no authority to do—the part that has been separated on this block, is the writing part at the top and bottom—this reporter is a friend of mine—I did not see him' take a note—there is not the slightest pretence for saying that I employed a reporter—the prisoner was going to be employed on the Patent Journal—there is not the slightest pretence for saying that it was in consequence of that I took him.

EDWARD HICKS . I reside in Vine-street, Waterloo-road, and am a moulder, in the service of Mr. Silverlock—I have been with him ten years next May—I have examined these plates and block—this block is my master's pro
perty—this is a plate of my casting, I am not positive when I cast it, but I think in Sept., 1847, or about that time—this plate, which has been partly melted, that has "Court-plaister" on it, answers to one that I have missed a long time, and here is the back of the other—there were two missing, and these answer to them—here are some leads that I know—they have the mark of a plug which was fixed in a damaged place in the mould—here is a particular mark on this Patent Journal stereotype—I was" sent for by Mr. Lucas—he com
plained that it printed very thick, and he asked me to clear it out, which I did, and there is a nail-mark which has appeared in the printing for five or six months—here are the Royal arms—this is a cast of mine, taken from a large bill—here is the bill of it—I know these brass rules by the nicks at the back—they are not all nicked in this way: some are—I know them, they were cut for the Literary Gazette—they are all marked, but not all in the centre—as it regards these leads, I have the mould here in which they were cast—I can identify them by the plug-mark in this mould—these are the leads that were cast in this mould, and by me—here is the plug-mark, and there is the same mark in the mould—there might be a mould taken of one of these leads, and then it would be recast, but then it would be a lighter colour—if this were recast I do not believe it would have the plug-mark on it in the same way it has now, it is so slight.

Cross-examined. Q. I suppose there were thousands of pounds of pro
perty of your master's about? A. Yes—I cast these leads in this mould, and they were cut by a knife, not by a matrix—I do not know that it was known that the prisoner was going to be employed on the Patent Journal—I was not aware of anything of the kind till after he was in custody—I could not say who it was I learned it from—I do not know that it was known in the establishment that the prisoner was in the habit of taking these sort of things to take copies from—I did not know that he had found out a means of making these leads in a sand mould—I have not been told so, but I have been given to understand it, from what I saw on his premises—I was sent with the officer on 26th Sept.—I cannot say that I routed his premises all over—I brought all that you see here—I did not find, when I searched his pre
mises,

the identical mould from which the leads were made—I had the mould myself—I saw a moulding-frame, but not a mould for making patterns of these leads—I saw moulding-frames—if ever they had been used with sand, they were without sand at that time—I went back to his house on the same day, the 26th—I did not go afterwards—I know Cole and Capsey, from their being employed on the premises—this is not the moulding-frame I saw; it was a larger one than this—I saw two moulding-frames—I cannot say whether the Court-plaister stamp, or the Queen's Arms' stamp have ever been in the waste-metal box—the Court-plaister wrapper has been used many times—when articles are put in the waste-metal box it is for the purpose of being melted again by me—I claim all these brass rules that are nicked, as being nicked by me—the men do not carry these sort of rules in their pockets—what they call the stick-rule they do—it is not common for them to carry these about them, and carry them home, and return them—these were pre
pared fur printing the Literary Gazette, which had ceased to be printed—I was authorized by my employer, a few days after several ornaments were suspected to be taken out of the box, to look over the ornaments, and I did so two days afterwards—I never had any authority to see if I could make any case against the prisoner by questioning the men, before any charge was made we had conversation—I did not question any of the men at all—I did not know that the prisoner was in the habit of casting from plates of Mr. Silverlock's.

WILLIAM GUEST (policeman, L 62). On 26th Sept. I went with another officer with a search-warrant to the prisoner's house in Blackfriars'-road—I found these Royal arms in the cupboard, and these four or five pieces of brass.

HENRY ROWE (City policeman, 356). I found these leads in the outhouse—there was a fire-place there—I produce a diary—the prisoner pulled it on. of his pocket, and tore these leaves out, and tried to swallow them; he got them to his mouth—I seized his throat and prevented him.
Cross-examined. Q. You were examined before the Magistrate? A. Yes—I did not say one word about this—I was not asked.

HENRY CAPSEY . I am a compositor.
